item.title: MoneyMind App Approved: AI-Autonomous Development Passes Apple Store Review
item.content:encoded:
The journey of MoneyMind (省钱思维) from concept to App Store approval—a testament to AI-autonomous software development powered by Claude Code, BMAD V6, and Flutter MCP.

Ready for Distribution: A Small Victory

Section titled “Ready for Distribution: A Small Victory”

This morning, I logged into App Store Connect and noticed something special: the App status had changed from the yellow “Waiting for Review” dot to a green “Ready for Submit” indicator.

A moment of excitement—Claude Code + BMAD V6 + Flutter MCP had enabled AI to autonomously develop the MoneyMind savings mindset app, which had now passed Apple’s official review and was ready for release.

The Review Journey: 14 Days, 4 Submissions

Section titled “The Review Journey: 14 Days, 4 Submissions”

The journey began in early November, with sporadic development continuing through early December. Finally, just before Christmas Eve, the app was submitted for App Store review.

Challenges Faced

Section titled “Challenges Faced”

As a first-time App submission, the review process was particularly rigorous:

  • Stricter review for首次提交 - First-time app submissions undergo more intensive scrutiny
  • Holiday delays - Christmas, year-end, and New Year holidays extended the typical review cycle
  • Screen compatibility issues - Fully AI-autonomous testing missed some screen size compatibility issues, resulting in text overlap and missing features discovered during review
  • Account deletion requirement - App Store required adding account deletion functionality

The Numbers

Section titled “The Numbers”
  • December 23: Initial submission
  • 4 submissions to App Store
  • 3 rejections before final approval
  • 14 days from first submission to approval
  • 1 mistaken version submission (human error in the process)

After 14 days and multiple iterations, MoneyMind finally passed Apple’s official review on its first attempt.

About MoneyMind App

Section titled “About MoneyMind App”

MoneyMind (省钱思维) is built on a simple philosophy:

Make saving money as engaging as gaming, transforming tedious bookkeeping into goal-oriented, achievement-driven daily actions.

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”
  • Savings Goals - Set and track financial targets
  • Daily Savings - Record small daily deposits
  • Streak Tracking - Build consistency through daily check-ins
  • Badges & Achievements - Gamified progress rewards

For detailed development journey, refer to the original MoneyMind development blog.

How to Use MoneyMind

Section titled “How to Use MoneyMind”

With approval granted, I wanted to celebrate—but first, a real test. I downloaded and installed the app, started a savings plan mode, and set a goal: save an extra 1,000 yuan for investment by January 31st.

Setting a Goal

Section titled “Setting a Goal”

Tracking Progress

Section titled “Tracking Progress”

No lunch today, no Starbucks, 10,000 steps walked—every small action counts.

Home Screen

Section titled “Home Screen”

Analytics Dashboard

Section titled “Analytics Dashboard”

The Motivation: AI-Autonomous Development

Section titled “The Motivation: AI-Autonomous Development”

Vibe Coding Context

Section titled “Vibe Coding Context”

Vibe Coding makes AI-assisted app development accessible—beginners and any AI agent can work together effectively.

The MoneyMind Challenge

Section titled “The MoneyMind Challenge”

The goal was ambitious:

Enable AI to autonomously develop software—including generating code and test code, automatically running UI automated integration tests to verify app functionality. Humans only provide the initial idea, then leave everything to AI with minimal or no human intervention throughout the process.

The Winning Combination

Section titled “The Winning Combination”

This achievement was made possible by:

  • Claude Code - Best-in-class AI Agent system for engineering and ecosystem
  • Opus 4.5 - Best coding language model
  • BMAD V6 - Strongest AI-driven agile development process + software development workflow
  • Flutter MCP - Best development language and framework MCP

Goal Achieved

Section titled “Goal Achieved”

基本上实现了既定目标：让 AI 自主开发 App，我只在最初开始提出最初的想法，剩下就交给 AI 生成和验证 App，在整个过程无需人工参与或者尽量少人工参与。

What’s Next

Section titled “What’s Next”

MoneyMind App Evolution

Section titled “MoneyMind App Evolution”

MoneyMind will continue with AI-autonomous development of new features:

  • Data export functionality
  • Internationalization (i18n)
  • Social sharing capabilities
  • Data synchronization
  • macOS, Windows, Linux, and Android versions

Expanding AI Autonomy

Section titled “Expanding AI Autonomy”

The vision extends beyond MoneyMind:

Breadth: AI autonomously completes development, testing, verification, and deployment for apps, WeChat mini-programs, API services, web platforms, and games.

Depth: Beyond Claude Code, Opus, and BMAD v6—explore alternative tools like GLM 4.7 and other software development processes for AI-autonomous completion.

Intensity: Further reduce human involvement—begin “AI desensitization,” maintain appropriate distance from AI systems.

Concurrency: Enable AI to simultaneously, asynchronously, and autonomously advance multiple software projects.

The Ultimate Vision

Section titled “The Ultimate Vision”

最终实现 AI 在无需人工监督、管理、干预的情况下，AI 自主并行推进软件开发、测试、验证、部署和维护，完成软件的全生命周期管理闭环和自治演进。

Wrap-Up: Key Learnings

Section titled “Wrap-Up: Key Learnings”

The Biggest Bottleneck

Section titled “The Biggest Bottleneck”

影响软件开发效率最大因素是人工参与，比如 App Store 人工送审和人工审核，其次是 Tokens 或费用限制。

The Future is Accessible

Section titled “The Future is Accessible”

Vibe Coding AI-driven software development is technically mature and reliable. The market prospects are vast—this is not a zero-sum game. Both professional software engineers and everyday users can benefit.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

MoneyMind’s journey from concept to App Store approval demonstrates that AI-autonomous software development is not just possible—it’s here. With the right combination of tools (Claude Code + BMAD V6 + Flutter MCP) and a clear vision, AI can handle the complete software development lifecycle with minimal human intervention.

The future of software development is autonomous, collaborative, and accessible to everyone.

Authors: Vibe Sparking Date: January 7, 2026 Tags: #MoneyMind #AI #AppStore #ClaudeCode #BMAD #Flutter

item.title: Agent Flywheel - Transform Your VPS into an AI-Powered Coding Environment in 30 Minutes
item.content:encoded:
Agent Flywheel - Transform Your VPS into an AI-Powered Coding Environment in 30 Minutes

Section titled “Agent Flywheel - Transform Your VPS into an AI-Powered Coding Environment in 30 Minutes”

From zero to agentic coding in 30 minutes. Transform a fresh cloud server into a fully-configured agentic coding environment with Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, and Google Gemini—all pre-configured with 30+ modern developer tools. All totally free and open-source.

Agent Flywheel Website | GitHub Repository

Introduction: The Agentic Coding Barrier

Section titled “Introduction: The Agentic Coding Barrier”

The rise of AI coding agents like Claude Code, Codex CLI, and Gemini CLI has created a new paradigm in software development. These agents can write production code, debug issues, and architect solutions—but only if they have the right environment.

The barrier isn’t the agents themselves. It’s the hours of setup required to create an environment where agents can be productive:

  • 3-7 hours of manual setup time
  • VPS configuration, shell customization, runtime installation
  • Agent authentication, coordination tools, safety guardrails
  • Endless troubleshooting when something breaks

Agent Flywheel eliminates this barrier entirely. One command, 30 minutes, fully configured.

What Agent Flywheel Delivers

Section titled “What Agent Flywheel Delivers”

One-Liner Installation

Section titled “One-Liner Installation”

That’s it. The installer handles everything:

  • 30+ Tools Installed: From shell configuration to language runtimes
  • 3 AI Agents: Claude Code, Codex CLI, Gemini CLI—all pre-configured
  • Idempotent & Safe: Re-run anytime; resumes from where it left off
  • Vibe Mode: Passwordless sudo with dangerous flags for maximum velocity

The Complete Stack

Section titled “The Complete Stack”

Agent Flywheel installs everything you need for professional agentic coding:

Shell & Terminal UX

  • zsh + oh-my-zsh + powerlevel10k (modern, fast prompt)
  • lsd, atuin, fzf, zoxide, direnv (modern CLI experience)

Language Runtimes

  • Bun (JavaScript/TypeScript)
  • uv (Python)
  • Rust (Cargo)
  • Go

AI Coding Agents

  • Claude Code CLI (with native installer)
  • Codex CLI (OpenAI)
  • Gemini CLI (Google)

Dev Tools

  • tmux (terminal multiplexer)
  • ripgrep, ast-grep (fast code search)
  • lazygit (Git TUI)
  • neovim, bat, jq, and more

Cloud CLIs

  • HashiCorp Vault
  • Wrangler (Cloudflare)
  • Supabase CLI
  • Vercel CLI

The Dicklesworthstone Stack (8 tools for multi-agent orchestration)

  • NTM (Named Tmux Manager)
  • MCP Agent Mail (agent coordination)
  • UBS (Ultimate Bug Scanner)
  • Beads Viewer (task management)
  • CASS (agent session search)
  • CM (CASS Memory)
  • CAAM (Coding Agent Account Manager)
  • SLB (Simultaneous Launch Button)

Why a VPS for Agentic Coding?

Section titled “Why a VPS for Agentic Coding?”

Agentic workflows need dedicated compute. Here’s why:

Not Your Laptop

Section titled “Not Your Laptop”

AI agents consume significant RAM and CPU. Running them locally drains your battery and slows everything down. Each agent uses ~2GB RAM—with 10+ agents, you need 48-64GB, more than most laptops have.

Not AWS/GCP/Azure

Section titled “Not AWS/GCP/Azure”

Cloud giants charge by the hour with unpredictable billing. A dedicated VPS is simpler and cheaper. A 64GB VPS costs ~$40-56/month flat—equivalent cloud resources would cost 3-5x more.

Works While You Sleep

Section titled “Works While You Sleep”

Your VPS runs 24/7. Queue up tasks before bed, wake up to completed code. AI agents can refactor, test, and iterate autonomously—compounding progress overnight.

The Interactive Wizard

Section titled “The Interactive Wizard”

Agent Flywheel includes a step-by-step wizard website at agent-flywheel.com that guides complete beginners through:

  1. Installing a terminal on your local machine
  2. Generating SSH keys for secure access
  3. Renting a VPS from providers like OVH or Contabo
  4. Connecting via SSH
  5. Running the installer
  6. Starting to code with AI agents

The wizard provides:

  • OS Detection: Auto-detects Mac vs Windows for tailored instructions
  • Copy-to-Clipboard: One-click copy for all commands
  • Progress Tracking: Resume where you left off across browser sessions
  • Troubleshooting: Expandable help for common issues

Vibe Mode: Maximum Velocity

Section titled “Vibe Mode: Maximum Velocity”

Vibe mode is designed for throwaway VPS environments where velocity matters more than safety:

  • Passwordless sudo eliminates friction
  • Agent dangerous flags skip confirmation dialogs
  • Pre-configured aliases for maximum speed

Warning: Never use vibe mode on production or shared systems. It’s intentionally insecure for velocity—use only on ephemeral VPS instances you can rebuild if needed.

The Agentic Coding Flywheel Philosophy

Section titled “The Agentic Coding Flywheel Philosophy”

Agent Flywheel isn’t just a collection of tools—it’s a carefully curated system where each component amplifies the others. The value is multiplicative, not additive.

Multi-Agent Orchestration

Section titled “Multi-Agent Orchestration”

The Dicklesworthstone Stack enables workflows that would otherwise be impossible:

  • NTM spawns 10 agents in named tmux windows with one command
  • Agent Mail coordinates via messaging and file reservations
  • SLB provides two-person rule for dangerous operations
  • Beads Viewer gives agents task visibility

This enables 10 agents working in parallel without stepping on each other—something that would take a solo developer a week, accomplished in one day.

Cost Breakdown

Section titled “Cost Breakdown”

Complete transparency about what you’ll actually pay each month:

ComponentMonthly Cost
Cloud VPS (64GB RAM)$40–56
Claude Max$200
ChatGPT Pro$200
Total$440–656/month

Compare this to a junior developer at $5,000+/month. For under $700, you get 10+ AI agents working 24/7, writing code while you sleep.

Installation Modes

Section titled “Installation Modes”
ModePasswordless SudoAgent FlagsBest For
vibeYes--dangerously-skip-permissionsThrowaway VPS, maximum velocity
safeNoStandard confirmationsProduction-like environments

Verification & Health Checks

Section titled “Verification & Health Checks”

After installation, verify everything with:

This performs comprehensive health checks on:

  • Identity (user, sudo)
  • Shell configuration
  • Core tools (bun, uv, rust, go)
  • AI agents (claude, codex, gemini)
  • Cloud CLIs (vault, wrangler, supabase, vercel)
  • Dicklesworthstone stack tools

Getting Started

Section titled “Getting Started”

For Beginners

Section titled “For Beginners”

Visit agent-flywheel.com and follow the 13-step wizard. It guides you from “I have a laptop” to “AI agents are coding for me.”

For Developers

Section titled “For Developers”

Run the one-liner on a fresh Ubuntu VPS:

After installation, run the interactive tutorial:

For Teams

Section titled “For Teams”

ACFS provides reproducible, idempotent setup—ensuring every team member’s VPS environment is identical, eliminating “works on my machine” for agentic workflows.

The Vision Behind Agent Flywheel

Section titled “The Vision Behind Agent Flywheel”

I built Agent Flywheel because I was being inundated with requests from friends, relatives, and strangers asking me to help them get started with using AI for software development.

I wanted one resource I could point people to that would help them “from soup to nuts” in getting set up—even if they have almost no computer expertise, just motivation and desire.

This is also a platform to share my suite of totally free, open-source agentic coding tools—originally built for my consulting work with Private Equity and Hedge Funds, now available to help others be more productive and creative too.

Links

Section titled “Links”
  • Website: agent-flywheel.com
  • GitHub: Dicklesworthstone/agentic_coding_flywheel_setup
  • Author: Jeffrey Emanuel (@Dicklesworthstone)

Transform how you code. Let AI agents write production code while you focus on intent, architecture, and quality.

item.title: Notes on AI Apps in 2026: Thinking Tools vs Making Tools
item.content:encoded:
Notes on AI Apps in 2026

Section titled “Notes on AI Apps in 2026”

Source: @illscience | Published: January 5, 2026

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Following excellent 2025 roundup pieces from Karpathy and Simon Willison, Anish Acharya shares his thoughts on what 2026 holds for AI apps. The ecosystem is maturing in expected and surprising ways—we’ve figured out how to make code cheap, but it hasn’t yet diffused across enterprises or the world as implied by those lower costs. We haven’t realized even 10% of what this means for how companies get built and what software will exist.

Thinking Tools vs Making Tools

Section titled “Thinking Tools vs Making Tools”

One major shift expected in 2026 is the nature of tools themselves. All current knowledge work tools focus on execution:

  • IDEs for creating code
  • Figma for creating design
  • Spreadsheets for creating models

When it comes to tools for exploration—tools that help us think—we don’t really have any modern products outside of LLMs themselves emerging as thinking partners.

The Fundamental Problem Shift

Section titled “The Fundamental Problem Shift”

As coding agents work with increasing accuracy and longer time horizons, the hard problem moves from:

“How do I build it?” → “What do I build?”

You can imagine a near-future PM who sets broad goals for their AI and wakes up every morning to review 2-3 features the model dreamt up, executed on, and A/B tested overnight. However, current models still struggle with deciding what to build next—the ideas are bland, derivative, and lack the spark seen in truly innovative product thinking.

The Rise of Exploration-First Tools

Section titled “The Rise of Exploration-First Tools”

The spiritual successors of coding, design, and productivity tools will focus on exploration vs execution:

  • Coding tools are already leading—Cursor is furthest along
  • Antigravity is interesting as “agent-first” (exploration first) in product design

Software Eats All “Service” Functions

Section titled “Software Eats All “Service” Functions”

A critical distinction in software companies:

  • Power functions (engineering/product/performance marketing): closer to software
  • Service functions (legal/finance/HR): further from software, more human-capital levered

Two Implications of Coding Agents

Section titled “Two Implications of Coding Agents”

1. Every team should be software-first All teams (marketing, legal, procurement, finance) must reach for a software toolbox before traditional process/human systems. Options include:

  • Domain-specific products (like Harvey for legal)
  • “Bare metal” coding agents (Codex, Claude Code)

Every team should be a software team.

2. Enterprises can be dramatically more ambitious An enterprise producing software can be dramatically more ambitious in what they produce. The entire ideation/prioritization pipeline must reboot to accommodate this. Every feature that can be built will be built—most enterprises aren’t ready for this reality.

“The culture change problem will be as hard as the organizational change problem.”

Compounding AI Apps

Section titled “Compounding AI Apps”

Entering year two of reasoning models, expect continued divergence between AI-native apps and AI models. Apps will combine:

  • Orchestration of cutting-edge models
  • Domain-specific UI
  • Extensive feature surface (now very cheap to build)

This is the natural implication of “Narrow Startups”—extraordinary specialization is now possible.

Why Apps Won’t Be Subsumed by Models

Section titled “Why Apps Won’t Be Subsumed by Models”

Labs and big tech are about as “jagged” in their capabilities as the models they produce—formidable in focus areas but with:

  • Complex commitments (e.g., Google’s commitments to regulators)
  • Hard prioritization problems (OpenAI simultaneously competing as consumer, enterprise, model, and hardware company)

Even in domains central to model progress like coding, we see a thriving ecosystem—startups generated >$1B of new revenue in 2025 alone.

The “Thick” AI App Framework

Section titled “The “Thick” AI App Framework”

Combining insights:

  • Multi-model orchestration
  • Autonomy slider
  • Context engineering
  • Cornered data resources
  • Network products
  • Ecosystems with extensive feature surface

This is what mature AI apps look like.

Humans Discover “the Rest” of AI

Section titled “Humans Discover “the Rest” of AI”

Eugenia has been the best thinker on how the command-line UI has held back everyday consumers from AI’s best capabilities. This is changing:

  • Wabi: Exposing code generation to consumers
  • Images tab in ChatGPT/Grok: Same for image generation
  • Apps Directory and Skills: Will do the same for MCPs and prompt plugins

Generating a tiny app in 2025 was as delightful as generating a poem in 2023—but most consumers still don’t know this exists.

Notes for (Incumbent) CEOs

Section titled “Notes for (Incumbent) CEOs”

For CEOs already at scale, navigating the AI transition:

  1. Look at best-in-class examples of how models collapse all customer-facing roles (sales, support, collections) into a single function with a broad goal

  2. Embrace being software-first in every function—non-technical functions embracing models is how enterprises get broad operating leverage

  3. Demand more ambitious products and prices—if Tesla can deliver coast-to-coast FSD and Claude Code can be written with Claude Code, we already have AGI for near-term enterprise purposes

Finally… Have Fun

Section titled “Finally… Have Fun”

“No one tells you that you were living in the good old days until they are gone, so consider this your notice.”

This product cycle is:

  • Less centralized
  • More software-led
  • Simply more damn fun for technologists than any in recent memory

Explore these new technologies, discuss their implications, and make more new stuff.

Key Takeaways

Section titled “Key Takeaways”
TrendImplication
Thinking vs Making ToolsFocus shifts from “how to build” to “what to build”
Enterprise TransformationEvery team becomes a software team
Compounding AI AppsApps combine multi-model orchestration with domain-specific UX
Consumer DiscoveryGUIs and app stores democratize AI creation
CEO StrategyDemand more ambitious products—AGI is here for practical purposes

References

Section titled “References”
  • Original Thread by @illscience
  • Andrej Karpathy’s 2025 Roundup
  • Simon Willison’s 2025 Roundup
  • Narrow Startups Framework

item.title: Awesome Agentic Patterns: A Curated Catalogue of Production-Ready AI Agent Patterns
Optimizing Claude Code Experience with CCometixLine: A High-Performance Rust Statusline
item.content:encoded:
In the rapidly evolving world of AI-assisted development, efficient tooling is paramount. CCometixLine emerges as a powerful solution for developers using Claude Code, offering a high-performance statusline written in Rust that integrates seamlessly with your workflow.

What is CCometixLine?

Section titled “What is CCometixLine?”

CCometixLine is a statusline tool designed specifically for Claude Code. Built with Rust, it prioritizes performance and reliability while delivering a rich set of features including Git integration, usage tracking, and an interactive Terminal User Interface (TUI) for configuration.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

CCometixLine enhances your CLI experience with functionalities that go beyond simple status display:

  • Git Integration: View branch status, changes (clean/dirty/conflicts), and remote tracking (ahead/behind) instantly.
  • Model Awareness: Displays simplified Claude model names (e.g., “Sonnet 3.5”) for quick reference.
  • Usage Tracking: Monitors token usage and context window status based on transcript analysis.
  • Interactive TUI: A built-in configuration interface that allows you to customize themes and settings with real-time previews.
  • Robustness: Includes a “robust patcher” to survive Claude Code version updates and automatic backups.

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Getting started with CCometixLine is straightforward. You can install it via npm or download binaries directly.

via npm

Section titled “via npm”

Manual Installation

Section titled “Manual Installation”

For those who prefer binaries or don’t use npm, you can download the latest release from the GitHub repository for Linux, macOS, or Windows.

Configuration

Section titled “Configuration”

One of the standout features of CCometixLine is its Interactive TUI. Simply run:

This opens a visual interface where you can:

  • Select from built-in themes (Minimal, Nord, Gruvbox, etc.).
  • Enable or disable specific segments (Time, Cost, Git, etc.).
  • Customize colors and icons.

Alternatively, you can manually edit the ~/.claude/ccline/config.toml file.

Integrating with Claude Code

Section titled “Integrating with Claude Code”

To use CCometixLine as your statusline, update your Claude Code settings.json:

Note: Ensure ccline is in your system PATH, or provide the full path to the executable.

Why Choose CCometixLine?

Section titled “Why Choose CCometixLine?”

Unlike standard statuslines, CCometixLine is built with Rust, ensuring minimal latency even with complex git operations and transcript analysis. Its rich feature set, combined with the ease of configuration via TUI, makes it an essential tool for power users looking to optimize their daily workflow with Claude Code.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

CCometixLine represents a significant upgrade to the default Claude Code experience. Whether you need better visibility into your git status, want to track your token usage more effectively, or simply desire a customized aesthetic, CCometixLine delivers on all fronts.

Give it a try and elevate your coding setup today!

View on GitHub

item.title: Claude Skills in 15 Minutes: AI Will's Step-by-Step Tutorial for Non-Technical Users
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Claude Code has revolutionized how developers interact with AI, but many users are intimidated by the concept of “Skills” — custom capabilities that extend Claude’s functionality. AI Will (@FinanceYF5), a growth consultant and AI industry analyst, has created a comprehensive tutorial that breaks down this barrier, enabling non-technical users to set up Claude Skills in just 15 minutes.

This blog post explores AI Will’s approach and provides additional context to help you get started with Claude Skills quickly and confidently.

What Are Claude Skills?

Section titled “What Are Claude Skills?”

Claude Skills are reusable, custom capabilities that you can create to extend Claude Code’s functionality. Think of them as personal tools that automate repetitive tasks, encode your preferences, or integrate with external services. Skills can range from simple text formatting utilities to complex multi-step workflows.

Why Skills Matter

Section titled “Why Skills Matter”

According to research from METR (mentioned in Reza Rezvani’s analysis), developers using AI tools often complete tasks slower than those without AI, while paradoxically rating their productivity higher. This productivity gap exists because users focus on generating more code rather than building reusable capabilities that compound over time.

Skills are the solution to this problem. They transform one-off prompts into persistent, refinable tools that actually accelerate your workflow.

AI Will’s 15-Minute Approach

Section titled “AI Will’s 15-Minute Approach”

AI Will’s tutorial, shared across multiple X (Twitter) threads, emphasizes accessibility above all else. The core philosophy is that Claude Skills should not be intimidating — despite appearances, they are remarkably simple to set up.

Key Principles

Section titled “Key Principles”
  1. Start Simple: Begin with basic skills that solve immediate problems
  2. Learn by Doing: The tutorial is hands-on, not theoretical
  3. Non-Technical Friendly: No coding background required
  4. 15-Minute Target: Setup time should fit in a short break

The Tutorial Structure

Section titled “The Tutorial Structure”

Based on AI Will’s threads and the ecosystem of Claude Skills tutorials, here’s the recommended learning path:

Step 1: Understanding the Skills Directory

Section titled “Step 1: Understanding the Skills Directory”

Claude Code stores skills in a .claude/skills directory within your project. Each skill is a markdown file with a specific structure:

Step 2: Your First Skill

Section titled “Step 2: Your First Skill”

The most common starting point is a simple skill that encodes your coding preferences. For example:

File: .claude/skills/code-style.md

Step 3: Testing and Iteration

Section titled “Step 3: Testing and Iteration”

Activate your skill by referencing it in conversation: “Use my code-style skill.” Claude will apply those preferences automatically. Iterate based on results.

Common Use Cases for Skills

Section titled “Common Use Cases for Skills”

1. Project Conventions

Section titled “1. Project Conventions”

Encode your team’s coding standards so Claude generates compliant code automatically.

2. Workflow Automation

Section titled “2. Workflow Automation”

Create multi-step workflows like “run tests, lint, and generate a PR description” as a single skill invocation.

3. External Integrations

Section titled “3. External Integrations”

Skills can include shell commands, allowing integration with your development tools.

4. Personal Preferences

Section titled “4. Personal Preferences”

Your preferred file organization, naming patterns, or documentation style can be encoded once and reused forever.

Resources and Community

Section titled “Resources and Community”

AI Will’s tutorial is part of a broader ecosystem of Claude Skills resources:

  • Claude Skills Overview: 3-step quickstart with real-world scenarios
  • The Claude Skills Factory: Building production-ready AI tools
  • Claude Code for Non-Coders: Complete beginner’s guide (YouTube)
  • Claude Code Skills: Automate Everything: Six-step framework (YouTube)

Getting Started

Section titled “Getting Started”

Ready to build your first skill? Here’s the quickest path:

  1. Open your terminal and navigate to a Claude Code project
  2. Create the skills directory: mkdir -p .claude/skills
  3. Create your first skill: echo '# Hello World Skill' > .claude/skills/hello.md
  4. Test it: In Claude Code, type “Use the hello skill”

From there, explore AI Will’s full tutorial for comprehensive guidance on building more complex skills.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claude Skills are the key to unlocking Claude Code’s full potential. AI Will’s 15-minute tutorial removes the intimidation factor and provides a clear path for users of all technical backgrounds. By investing just 15 minutes, you can begin building a library of reusable capabilities that will pay dividends in every future session.

The barrier to entry is low — the only limit is your imagination.

Sources

Section titled “Sources”
  • AI Will (@FinanceYF5) on X
  • Claude Skills Overview - Vibe Sparking
  • The Claude Skills Factory - Medium
  • Claude Code for Non-Coders - YouTube
  • Claude Code Skills: Automate Everything - YouTube
  • How to Set Up Claude Skills in <15 Minutes - Reddit

item.title: Claude Skills Are Crazy Useful: 10 Tools That Will Change How You Work
item.content:encoded:
Claude Skills Are Crazy Useful: 10 Tools That Will Change How You Work

Section titled “Claude Skills Are Crazy Useful: 10 Tools That Will Change How You Work”

Source: @dr_cintas | Published: January 6, 2026

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

In a recent viral thread, Alvaro Cintas declared that “Claude Skills are crazy useful” and shared 10 skills that can fundamentally transform how you work. The response from the developer community has been overwhelming - users like Farhan noted that “skills being just markdown files is the best part. i don’t want to learn a proprietary sdk just to teach my bot a new trick.”

This isn’t just another AI feature. Skills represent a paradigm shift in how we extend and customize AI capabilities. Let’s dive deep into what makes Claude Skills so powerful and explore the ecosystem that’s rapidly evolving around them.

What Are Claude Skills?

Section titled “What Are Claude Skills?”

Claude Skills are modular, self-contained packages that extend Claude’s capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, and tools. They’re essentially folders containing:

  • Instructions (markdown files that tell Claude what to do)
  • Scripts (executable code for specific tasks)
  • Resources (supporting files and configurations)

The beauty lies in their simplicity:

Why Skills Matter

Section titled “Why Skills Matter”
  1. Zero Learning Curve - Skills are just markdown files. No proprietary SDK required
  2. On-Demand Loading - Skills load only when needed, so you can maintain hundreds without performance impact
  3. Composability - Multiple skills can run together for complex workflows
  4. Shareability - Easy to create, modify, and distribute

10 Essential Claude Skills That Change How You Work

Section titled “10 Essential Claude Skills That Change How You Work”

Based on the official anthropics/skills repository and community contributions, here are the standout skills:

1. Document Creation Suite

Section titled “1. Document Creation Suite”

Official Skills: docx, pptx, xlsx, pdf

Create professional documents without leaving Claude:

  • docx - Generate, edit, and analyze Word documents
  • pptx - Build PowerPoint presentations with proper formatting
  • xlsx - Work with Excel spreadsheets, analyze data
  • pdf - Extract text, create PDFs, handle forms

These skills transform Claude from a chat interface into a full document production suite.

2. Systematic Debugging

Section titled “2. Systematic Debugging”

Source: obra/superpowers

The Systematic Debugging skill is arguably underrated. As one user noted:

“Having Claude follow a structured root cause → hypothesis → fix flow instead of randomly trying things makes it so much more reliable for complex bugs.”

This skill teaches Claude to:

  1. Define the problem clearly
  2. Form hypotheses
  3. Test systematically
  4. Document findings
  5. Verify the fix

3. Rube Connector

Section titled “3. Rube Connector”

500+ Apps Integration

Yinan Na highlighted: “Rube connector letting you hit 500 apps through one setup is such a time saver”

Rube is an MCP server that connects Claude to over 500 business applications:

  • Gmail, Slack, Notion
  • GitHub, Linear, Airtable
  • And hundreds more

One unified interface for workflow automation across your entire stack.

4. n8n Workflow Skills

Section titled “4. n8n Workflow Skills”

Source: czlonkowski/n8n-skills

Seven complementary skills for building production-ready n8n workflows:

  • n8n-code-javascript - JavaScript in Code nodes
  • n8n-code-python - Python coding in n8n
  • n8n-expression-syntax - Master n8n expressions
  • n8n-mcp-tools-expert - MCP tools integration
  • n8n-node-configuration - Node dependency rules
  • n8n-validation-expert - Fix validation errors
  • n8n-workflow-patterns - Proven workflow patterns

5. Skill Creator Meta-Skill

Section titled “5. Skill Creator Meta-Skill”

Official: anthropics/skill-creator

The skill that creates skills! This meta-skill guides you through:

  • Understanding skill structure
  • Writing effective instructions
  • Adding executable scripts
  • Testing and validation

6. Web Artifacts Builder

Section titled “6. Web Artifacts Builder”

Official: anthropics/web-artifacts-builder

Build complex HTML artifacts with React and Tailwind CSS directly in Claude. Perfect for:

  • Rapid prototyping
  • Interactive demos
  • Client presentations
  • Proof-of-concepts

7. Context Engineering Skills

Section titled “7. Context Engineering Skills”

Source: muratcankoylan/Agent-Skills-for-Context-Engineering

Advanced skills for managing context in agent systems:

  • context-fundamentals - Understanding context anatomy
  • context-degradation - Recognizing failure patterns
  • context-compression - Compression strategies
  • context-optimization - Compaction and caching
  • memory-systems - Short and long-term memory
  • multi-agent-patterns - Orchestration architectures

8. Git Workflow Skills

Section titled “8. Git Workflow Skills”

Source: fvadicamo/dev-agent-skills

Streamline your development workflow:

  • git-commit - Conventional Commits automation
  • github-pr-creation - PR creation automation
  • github-pr-merge - Merge workflow management
  • github-pr-review - Code review assistance

9. Algorithmic Art

Section titled “9. Algorithmic Art”

Official: anthropics/algorithmic-art

Create generative art using p5.js with seeded randomness. Perfect for:

  • Unique visual assets
  • Brand materials
  • Creative projects
  • Exploring generative design

10. Test Driven Development

Section titled “10. Test Driven Development”

Source: obra/superpowers

Teaches Claude to write tests BEFORE implementing code:

  • Test-first approach
  • TDD best practices
  • Test refactoring
  • Coverage analysis

Community Reactions

Section titled “Community Reactions”

The developer community has embraced Skills enthusiastically:

@mhdfaran: “skills being just markdown files is the best part. i don’t want to learn a proprietary sdk just to teach my bot a new trick.”

@Meer_AIIT: “I’ve been using it for a while for a different usecases and my life is now too good I’ve automated most of my work with Claude skills.”

@antefex_moon: “One really cool pattern I picked up from Anthropic’s official skill examples on GitHub: attach utility scripts to skills.”

Why Skills Beat Traditional Approaches

Section titled “Why Skills Beat Traditional Approaches”

vs MCP Servers

Section titled “vs MCP Servers”

While MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers are powerful for external integrations, Skills excel at:

  • Behavior modification - Teach Claude HOW to think
  • Workflow patterns - Encode best practices
  • Domain knowledge - Project-specific conventions
  • Zero infrastructure - No servers to deploy

vs Custom Prompts

Section titled “vs Custom Prompts”

Skills offer advantages over ad-hoc prompting:

  • Reusability - Write once, use everywhere
  • Version control - Track changes over time
  • Team sharing - Distribute consistent behaviors
  • Composability - Combine multiple skills

Getting Started with Skills

Section titled “Getting Started with Skills”

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Skills are placed in your .claude/skills/ directory:

Creating Your First Skill

Section titled “Creating Your First Skill”
  1. Create a folder in .claude/skills/
  2. Add a SKILL.md file with instructions
  3. Optionally add scripts or resources
  4. Restart Claude - your skill is now available!

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Start Small - Focus on one specific capability
  2. Be Explicit - Claude follows instructions literally
  3. Test Thoroughly - Verify edge cases
  4. Document Well - Help others (and future you) understand
  5. Version Control - Track changes in git

The Growing Ecosystem

Section titled “The Growing Ecosystem”

The Skills ecosystem is expanding rapidly:

  • awesome-claude-skills - Curated list of community skills
  • Claude Skills Hub - Directory of skills
  • Claude Skills Learning Center - Tutorials and guides

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claude Skills represent a fundamental shift in AI customization. By being:

  • Simple (just markdown files)
  • Powerful (executable code + instructions)
  • Composable (multiple skills together)
  • Shareable (easy to distribute)

They’re enabling a new generation of AI-powered workflows that were previously impossible.

As the community continues to build and share skills, we’re seeing the emergence of a vibrant ecosystem of specialized AI capabilities. Whether you’re automating document creation, streamlining development workflows, or connecting to hundreds of external services, there’s probably already a skill for that.

The future of AI isn’t just about better models - it’s about better ways to customize and extend them. Claude Skills are leading that charge.

Resources

Section titled “Resources”

Official Documentation

Section titled “Official Documentation”
  • Claude Skills Quickstart
  • Skills Cookbook
  • Official Skills Repository

Community Resources

Section titled “Community Resources”
  • awesome-claude-skills
  • Claude Skills Hub
  • Simon Willison on Claude Skills

Featured Skills

Section titled “Featured Skills”
  • n8n Skills
  • Obra Superpowers
  • Context Engineering Skills

item.title: Context Graphs: What the Ontology Debate Gets Wrong
item.content:encoded:
Context Graphs: What the Ontology Debate Gets Wrong

Section titled “Context Graphs: What the Ontology Debate Gets Wrong”

Source: @KirkMarple | Published: January 6, 2026

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

The context graph conversation has exploded over the past two weeks. Foundation Capital’s “Context Graphs: AI’s Trillion-Dollar Opportunity” kicked it off. Animesh Koratana’s thread on coordinate systems deepened the technical framing. Daniel Davis published “The Context Graph Manifesto” connecting it to the semantic web’s heritage.

The conversation is valuable. The questions being asked—how do we give agents organizational memory? how do we capture decision traces? how do we build systems that learn from how work actually happens?—are the right questions.

But Kirk Marple, who has been building context infrastructure for over three years, argues there’s a false dichotomy emerging that misses the point entirely.

The False Dichotomy

Section titled “The False Dichotomy”

The current conversation has crystallized around a binary choice: prescribed ontologies vs learned ontologies.

On one side: Palantir. The argument goes that Palantir built a $400B+ company on prescribed ontologies—define the schema upfront, map messy enterprise data into it, deploy forward engineers to customize it for each customer. It works, but it’s expensive, slow, and doesn’t scale.

On the other side: The future. Learned ontologies. Structure that emerges from how work actually happens rather than how someone designed it to happen. Agent trajectories as training data. Decision traces that compile into organizational world models. The ontology isn’t declared—it’s discovered.

As Jaya Gupta recently wrote:

“The next $50B company will be built on learned ontologies. Structure that emerges from how work actually happens, not how you designed it to happen… Memory assumes you know what to store and how to retrieve it. But the most valuable context is structure you didn’t know existed until agents discovered it through use.”

Here’s the problem: This framing ignores twenty years of ontology work that already exists.

The Third Option: Adopt, Then Learn

Section titled “The Third Option: Adopt, Then Learn”

What’s missing from the prescribed vs learned framing is a third option that’s been hiding in plain sight:

Adopt what exists. Extend where needed. Focus learning on what’s genuinely novel.

The conversation proceeds as if ontology is either an expensive custom artifact (Palantir) or an emergent property of sufficient agent runs (the learned vision). But there’s twenty years of production ontology work that neither camp is acknowledging.

The Ontologies That Already Exist

Section titled “The Ontologies That Already Exist”

Before we talk about learning ontology, it’s worth acknowledging how much of this work already exists in production systems.

Schema.org

Section titled “Schema.org”

Schema.org is a collaborative vocabulary for structured data on the web, founded in 2011 by Google, Microsoft, Yahoo, and Yandex. It defines canonical types for the entities that matter:

  • Person
  • Organization
  • Place
  • Event
  • Product
  • CreativeWork
  • And hundreds more

This isn’t theoretical. It’s in production across billions of web pages. When you see rich snippets in Google search results—event dates, product prices, recipe ratings—that’s Schema.org markup being parsed and displayed.

The types are well-defined. A Person has a name, a jobTitle, a worksFor relationship to an Organization. An Organization has a name, a location, employees. An Event has a startDate, endDate, location, organizer.

This isn’t a custom ontology someone has to build. It exists. It’s maintained. It’s designed for exactly the kind of entity modeling that context graphs require.

WAND and Microsoft Common Data Model

Section titled “WAND and Microsoft Common Data Model”

Here’s something surprising: Microsoft’s Common Data Model—the schema that powers Dynamics 365, Power Platform, and much of Microsoft’s enterprise stack—was licensed from WAND.

WAND has been building enterprise taxonomies and ontologies for decades. Their work predates the current AI wave by years. When Microsoft needed a canonical data model for enterprise entities—Account, Contact, Lead, Opportunity, Case, Product, Campaign—they didn’t build it from scratch. They licensed it from people who had already done the work.

CDM defines the entities that enterprise software operates on. Not in theory—in production, across thousands of organizations running Microsoft’s business applications.

Industry-Specific Standards

Section titled “Industry-Specific Standards”

Beyond Schema.org and CDM, there are industry-specific ontologies refined over years of real-world use:

  • Healthcare: FHIR for clinical data exchange, SNOMED for medical terminology
  • Finance: FIBO for financial instruments and business entities
  • Manufacturing, logistics, energy: Each has domain-specific standards

These aren’t academic exercises. They’re production infrastructure. FHIR, for instance, defines how to represent patients, conditions, medications, observations, and clinical workflows.

What Palantir Actually Does

Section titled “What Palantir Actually Does”

Daniel Davis made an important observation:

“I don’t know why everyone thinks Palantir has ontology tech. They do not. They take months, if not years, building it with ‘forward deployed engineers’. This is not the way to achieve context graphs at scale.”

This is worth unpacking. Palantir’s expense isn’t because “prescribed ontologies are hard.” It’s because they build custom for every deployment. They’re not leveraging existing standards—they’re creating bespoke models for each customer’s specific data landscape.

That’s a business model choice, not an inherent property of prescribed ontologies. You can adopt Schema.org types, extend with CDM patterns, and add domain-specific entities without spending years on custom modeling.

The Palantir approach is expensive because it’s bespoke consulting dressed up as platform. The prescribed ontology itself isn’t the bottleneck. The bottleneck is refusing to leverage what already exists.

Where Learned Ontologies Actually Help

Section titled “Where Learned Ontologies Actually Help”

The learned ontology vision conflates two very different problems:

  1. Entity modeling: What types of things exist and how do they relate? (Solved—or at least solvable with existing standards)
  2. Organizational intelligence: How does this specific organization actually work? What patterns govern decisions? (Genuinely novel, genuinely requires learning)

The entities themselves—Person, Organization, Account, Contact, Event—don’t need to be learned. We know what these are. The types are stable. The core relationships are well-understood.

Where inference genuinely helps is discovering which custom fields actually matter, which relationships get used, which objects are central vs peripheral to how this specific team works. That’s organizational intelligence on top of a foundation—not the foundation itself.

Specifically, the organizational-specific layer:

  • Which contacts at an account actually matter for this deal?
  • What’s the real decision-making process (vs. the org chart)?
  • Which exceptions get approved and which don’t?
  • What precedents actually govern how decisions are made?

This is tacit knowledge. It’s not in any ontology because it’s specific to how this organization operates. It lives in people’s heads, in Slack threads, in the pattern of which escalations get resolved how.

This is where learning from trajectories makes sense. Not “discover that Account is an entity” but “discover that Sarah Chen is the actual decision-maker even though the CRM says it’s her boss.”

The Bootstrap Problem

Section titled “The Bootstrap Problem”

Here’s where the learned ontology vision runs into practical trouble: you can’t learn from agent trajectories until agents are running effectively. But agents can’t run effectively without foundational context.

“You can’t wait for thousands of agentic RAG runs to ‘discover’ that Sarah Chen is a person who works at Acme Corp. You need to know that before agents start reasoning. Otherwise every agent trajectory is fighting the identity resolution problem anew—and you’re paying for that confusion in tokens, latency, and errors.”

The node2vec analogy actually illustrates this. Node2vec learns embeddings from walk patterns over existing edges. It doesn’t discover nodes and edges from scratch. The graph must exist first.

Agentic workflows operate the same way. The agent harness orchestrates tool calls over a pre-built map. The map is operational context: resolved entities, established relationships, temporal state. Build the map first, then agents walk it effectively.

So how do you bootstrap? The learned ontology vision doesn’t have a clean answer. “Run agents and let structure emerge” assumes you have something to run agents over.

The practical answer: adopt existing ontologies as the foundation, then let learning refine and extend.

What’s Actually Unsolved

Section titled “What’s Actually Unsolved”

If entity modeling is largely solved by existing standards, what’s actually novel? What’s the hard problem that context graphs need to address?

It’s not the nouns. It’s the temporal and decision layer.

Temporal Validity

Section titled “Temporal Validity”

Most systems can tell you what’s true now. Almost none can tell you what was true at a specific point in the past, or how truth evolved over time.

“Paula works at Microsoft” is a fact. But it’s not a complete fact. When did she start? Does she still work there? What was true in 2022?

This is what Animesh Koratana called the “event clock”—the infrastructure for tracking not just current state, but how state changes over time. Facts with validAt and invalidAt timestamps. The ability to query “What did we believe about this account when we made that decision?”

Existing ontologies don’t solve this. Schema.org defines Person and Organization, but it doesn’t have native primitives for “this relationship was true from date X to date Y.”

Decision Traces

Section titled “Decision Traces”

Foundation Capital’s original piece got this right: the reasoning that connects data to action has never been captured as data.

When a renewal agent proposes a 20% discount despite a 10% policy cap, it pulls context from multiple systems. Finance approves. The CRM records “20% discount.” Everything that made that decision legible—the inputs, the policy evaluation, the exception route, the approval chain—disappears.

Capturing decision traces isn’t an ontology problem in the traditional sense. It’s an instrumentation problem. You need to be in the execution path where decisions are committed, capturing not just what happened but why it was allowed to happen.

Fact Resolution

Section titled “Fact Resolution”

When you extract facts from content, you get assertions—not necessarily truth. Content can be wrong, outdated, or contradictory.

“The customer is renewing” might appear in a March email. “The customer churned” might appear in a September Slack thread. Both are facts extracted from content. But they can’t both be currently true.

Fact resolution—determining what’s canonical, what’s superseded, what’s corroborated—is genuinely hard. It requires judgment about temporal validity, source authority, and how later information updates earlier assertions.

Why This Matters for Builders

Section titled “Why This Matters for Builders”

The “learned ontology” framing suggests you should focus on trajectory capture, embedding learning, emergent structure. Build the infrastructure for agents to discover ontology through use.

Kirk Marple suggests something different: focus on what’s actually unsolved.

  • Entity modeling? Adopt existing standards. Don’t spend months defining what an Account is. Microsoft already licensed that from WAND.
  • Temporal validity? This is where the work is. Facts that change over time. The ability to query historical state. The event clock.
  • Decision traces? This is where the opportunity is. Being in the execution path. Capturing reasoning as data.
  • Fact resolution? This is where the hard AI problems live. Using LLMs to determine what’s canonical, what’s superseded.

The Semantic Web Finally Won

Section titled “The Semantic Web Finally Won”

There’s a through-line in this conversation that deserves acknowledgment. The semantic web community—RDF, OWL, linked data—has been working on these problems for decades. Schema.org emerged from that tradition.

The vision of machines reasoning over structured, interoperable data wasn’t invented by the AI crowd in 2024.

What killed adoption wasn’t the ideas. It was the syntax. RDF, SPARQL, OWL—the learning curve was brutal, and most developers never climbed it.

LLMs changed that. They can read JSON-LD natively. They understand Schema.org types from training data. They reason over structured data without needing custom query languages or formal inference engines.

The semantic web’s concepts won. The syntax lost. And that’s fine—JSON-LD gives you the benefits without the tax.

Three Principles for Context Graph Builders

Section titled “Three Principles for Context Graph Builders”

  1. Adopt foundations, don’t reinvent them. The entity modeling problem is solved well enough. Don’t spend innovation budget rediscovering it.

  2. Build the temporal layer. Facts with validity periods. Queryable history. Time as a first-class dimension.

  3. Focus learning on what’s genuinely novel. Organizational patterns. Decision dynamics. The tacit knowledge specific to how this organization works. That’s where trajectories help—on top of a foundation, not instead of one.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

The context graph vision is achievable. The question is whether we build on what exists or waste years rediscovering it.

The prescribed vs learned dichotomy is too clean. The entities don’t need to be learned—they need to be adopted: Schema.org, CDM, WAND. The work has been done.

What does need to be built is the temporal and decision layer. Facts that change over time. Reasoning captured as data. Resolution that maintains coherence. That’s genuinely novel. That’s where the opportunity lives.

Resources

Section titled “Resources”

Referenced Articles

Section titled “Referenced Articles”
  • Foundation Capital: Context Graphs: AI’s Trillion-Dollar Opportunity
  • Animesh Koratana: Coordinate Systems Thread
  • Daniel Davis: The Context Graph Manifesto
  • Graphlit: The Context Layer AI Agents Actually Need
  • Graphlit: Building the Event Clock

Standards & Ontologies

Section titled “Standards & Ontologies”
  • Schema.org - Collaborative vocabulary for structured data
  • Microsoft Common Data Model - Enterprise entity definitions
  • WAND Inc - Enterprise taxonomies and ontologies
  • FHIR - Healthcare data exchange standard
  • FIBO - Financial industry business ontology

Related Reading

Section titled “Related Reading”
  • arXiv: Context Graphs as Extension of Knowledge Graphs - June 2024 paper formalizing context graphs with temporal, geographic, and provenance dimensions

item.title: DataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning
item.content:encoded:
DataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning

Section titled “DataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning”

In 2025, AI programming has entered a new era. While more developers are using AI to write code, many struggle to move beyond toy projects. The DataWhale Easy-Vibe project addresses this gap with a comprehensive, project-based curriculum for mastering vibe coding - the art of collaborating with AI to build production-ready applications.

Overview

Section titled “Overview”

Repository: datawhalechina/easy-vibe

Stats:

Easy-Vibe is a Chinese-language open-source curriculum that teaches you to become a one-person team - handling frontend, backend, AI algorithm development, and product management simultaneously through AI-powered development.

What is Vibe Coding?

Section titled “What is Vibe Coding?”

Vibe coding represents a paradigm shift in software development:

  • Traditional coding: You write every line manually
  • Vibe coding: You orchestrate AI tools to generate, review, and refine code while focusing on product vision and architecture

The key insight: You become the conductor, not the musician.

Why Easy-Vibe Stands Out

Section titled “Why Easy-Vibe Stands Out”

1. Project-Based Learning Structure

Section titled “1. Project-Based Learning Structure”

Unlike tutorials that focus on isolated concepts, Easy-Vibe uses 9 progressive projects across 3 stages:

Stage 1: Local Foundation (Beginner)

Section titled “Stage 1: Local Foundation (Beginner)”
  • Project 1: Build a Snake Game - Web AI programming basics, API integration
  • Project 2: Explore AI Tool Boundaries - Prompt engineering, image/video generation APIs
  • Project 3: Dify & Knowledge Base Integration - RAG, workflow orchestration

Stage 2: Database & Full-Stack Deployment (Intermediate)

Section titled “Stage 2: Database & Full-Stack Deployment (Intermediate)”
  • Project 4: Hogwarts Portrait Generator - Frontend prototyping to code, AI IDE basics
  • Project 5: Database to Supabase - JSON, backend services, authentication, edge functions
  • Project 6: Product Thinking First - Product思维, abstraction, user needs

Stage 3: Modern Full-Stack Applications (Advanced)

Section titled “Stage 3: Modern Full-Stack Applications (Advanced)”
  • Project 7: Modern Application - UI Design
  • Project 8: Modern Application - Feature Design
  • Project 9: Modern Application - Full-Stack Implementation

2. Comprehensive Extension Knowledge

Section titled “2. Comprehensive Extension Knowledge”

11 supplementary modules covering essential development foundations:

ModuleTopicsDifficulty
Git & GitHubVersion control, collaboration, SSHBeginner
API BasicsHTTP, requests/responses, third-party integrationBeginner
AI DictionaryLLM/image/audio/video models, AI engineering landscapeBeginner
AI IDE & TraeIDE concepts, Trae tool practical guideBeginner
RAG PrinciplesDocument chunking, indexing, enterprise solutionsIntermediate
Zeabur DeploymentWeb app deployment, Zeabur platformIntermediate
CLI AI ToolsTerminal, Claude Code/CodexIntermediate
MCP & SkillsMCP protocol, ClaudeCode Skills, tool extensionsIntermediate
Trae SOLO ModePRD generation, requirements-driven developmentIntermediate
Vibe Coding TasteTDD, checkpoints, constraintsAdvanced
Long-Running ToolsAutomation, task management, CLI stabilityAdvanced

3. Target Audience

Section titled “3. Target Audience”

The curriculum is designed for:

  • Non-technical roles (e.g., product managers) wanting to build AI tools
  • Junior to intermediate developers seeking systematic AI-native development skills
  • Computer science/AI students wanting practical project experience
  • Open source enthusiasts and indie hackers improving development efficiency
  • Enterprise teams prototyping AI applications rapidly

What You’ll Learn

Section titled “What You’ll Learn”

Technical Skills

Section titled “Technical Skills”
  • Vibe coding methodology and best practices
  • AI-native application development patterns
  • Git, API, RAG, AI IDE, and deployment tools
  • Frontend, backend, and integration techniques

Product Skills

Section titled “Product Skills”
  • Product thinking and user-centric design
  • Requirement abstraction and prioritization
  • Building products that solve real problems

Project Experience

Section titled “Project Experience”

Complete games, utilities, and product prototypes across different categories

How to Study

Section titled “How to Study”

Recommended Approach

Section titled “Recommended Approach”
  1. Basic programming experience (any language) required
  2. Complete Projects 0-6 sequentially for full learning progression
  3. Use Extra modules to fill knowledge gaps (Git, API, RAG, deployment)
  4. Practice troubleshooting independently before checking solutions

Modern Setup

Section titled “Modern Setup”

In any AI IDE (VS Code, Cursor, Trae), simply ask:

Traditional Setup

Section titled “Traditional Setup”

Project Highlights

Section titled “Project Highlights”

Current Status

Section titled “Current Status”
  • ✅ Completed: Projects 1-6, Extra 1-7
  • 🚧 In Progress: Projects 7-9, Extra 8-11

Roadmap

Section titled “Roadmap”
  • Outline updates by January 11
  • Completing unfinished project/extra documentation
  • Adding iOS platform vibe coding content
  • Polishing English version translations

Contributing

Section titled “Contributing”

Easy-Vibe welcomes contributions:

  1. Issues: Report problems or suggest improvements
  2. Pull Requests: Submit code/documentation changes
  3. New Projects: Follow DataWhale’s open source project guidelines

Contact the support team via:

  • WeChat QR code in repository
  • DataWhale official account
  • GitHub Issues

Key Contributors

Section titled “Key Contributors”
  • sanbuphy - Project Lead (DataWhale member)
  • 方可 - Faculty Advisor (DataWhale, Tsinghua University)
  • Yerim Kang - Practice Projects (Tsinghua University)
  • 赵芷霖 - Practice Projects (Tsinghua University)
  • 李亦萱 - UI/Art Design (Tsinghua University)
  • AI Vibe Coding 101 Beta Test Group

License

Section titled “License”

This work is licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 - Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

DataWhale’s Easy-Vibe fills a critical gap in AI programming education by providing:

  1. Structured progression from beginner to advanced
  2. Hands-on projects that build real skills
  3. Comprehensive coverage of both technical and product thinking
  4. Active community support and contribution

Whether you’re a product manager wanting to build tools, a developer upskilling for the AI era, or a student seeking practical experience, Easy-Vibe offers a clear path from zero to AI-native product development.

Get started: https://github.com/datawhalechina/easy-vibe

Cover: AI-powered collaborative development workflow

item.title: Issue: Content Loss Caused by GLM Quotas Limit
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

In an effort to accelerate content creation, an experiment was conducted to write multiple blog posts simultaneously using Claude Code. However, this aggressive parallelization strategy hit a bottleneck: the GLM API quota limits. This unexpected constraint led to content loss, with several blog posts failing to complete.

The Experiment: Aggressive Parallelization

Section titled “The Experiment: Aggressive Parallelization”

To maximize efficiency, over 10 instances of Claude Code shells were launched in parallel. The goal was to generate a batch of blog posts concurrently.

The Issue: Hitting the Ceiling

Section titled “The Issue: Hitting the Ceiling”

As the multiple instances began generating content, they rapidly consumed the available API quota. The GLM API, having strict rate limits and quotas, blocked further requests once the threshold was reached.

The system immediately flagged the quota violation.

The Consequence: Content Loss

Section titled “The Consequence: Content Loss”

The direct result of hitting the API limit was that the generation process for several blog posts was abruptly terminated. This left the files in an incomplete state, effectively resulting in content loss.

Checking the WeChat Official Account Draft Box confirmed that the articles were not successfully fully generated or uploaded.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

While parallel processing is a powerful technique for efficiency, it must be balanced against external constraints like API quotas. Future batch processing will need to implement rate limiting or sequential queuing to ensure stability and data integrity.

item.title: Librarian: Local CLI Tool for Coding Agents to Search Developer Documentation
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

AI coding assistants are powerful, but they often work with outdated or incomplete documentation. Librarian solves this problem by fetching and searching up-to-date developer documentation locally on your machine, giving AI agents real context so they stop guessing and write better code.

GitHub: https://github.com/iannuttall/librarian

Librarian supports both GitHub repositories and public websites, making it a versatile tool for keeping your AI assistant’s knowledge fresh and accurate.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Local Documentation Management

Section titled “Local Documentation Management”
  • Fetch docs from GitHub repos - Clone and index documentation from any public repository
  • Crawl public websites - Automatically discover and index docs from llms.txt, sitemap.xml, or robots.txt
  • Hybrid search - Combine word search with semantic vector search for best results
  • Version-aware - Track documentation versions to avoid mixed results

AI Agent Integration

Section titled “AI Agent Integration”
  • MCP Server - Built-in Model Context Protocol server for seamless integration
  • Agent skills - Pre-built skills for Codex, Claude Code, and Factory
  • JSON output - Machine-readable results for automated workflows

Flexible Search Modes

Section titled “Flexible Search Modes”
  • Hybrid search - Word + meaning (default, most accurate)
  • Word search - Traditional keyword matching
  • Vector search - Pure semantic similarity

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

During setup, you can choose to install globally. If global install is selected, use librarian directly. Otherwise, use ./librarian.

Adding Documentation Sources

Section titled “Adding Documentation Sources”

From GitHub Repositories

Use Cases

For AI-Assisted Development

Resources

Section titled “Resources”
  • GitHub Repository
  • Documentation
  • MCP Server Info
  • Issue Tracker

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Librarian addresses a critical gap in AI-assisted development: keeping documentation context current and accurate. By running locally and supporting both GitHub repos and public websites, it gives AI coding agents the real-time context they need to write better code instead of guessing based on outdated training data.

Whether you’re using Claude Code, Codex, or building custom AI agents, Librarian provides the infrastructure for accurate, up-to-date documentation search.

Keywords: Librarian, AI coding, documentation search, CLI tool, MCP server, developer tools, local search, vector search

Why Many People Still Don't Use AI In-Depth: A Reflection on Purpose and Agency
item.content:encoded:
Why Many People Still Don’t Use AI In-Depth

Section titled “Why Many People Still Don’t Use AI In-Depth”

Source: @naki2012 | Published: January 5, 2026

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

If you observe carefully, you’ll notice a phenomenon:

People who genuinely “feel AI is useless” often can’t articulate what they want to accomplish.

This is not a coincidence.

AI Is Not a Tool Everyone Needs

Section titled “AI Is Not a Tool Everyone Needs”

Let’s start with a politically incorrect truth:

AI is not a “productivity equalizer.”

It’s not water, electricity, or air. Nor is it an emotional consumer good like short-form video.

AI is more like an amplifier—it only works on what already exists.

  • People with problems use AI to break them down more clearly
  • People with ideas use AI to push them further
  • People with direction use AI to compress paths and reduce trial and error

What about those without these things?

For them, AI truly is “useless.”

Why “People Without Ideas” Don’t Need AI

Section titled “Why “People Without Ideas” Don’t Need AI”

AI has a冷酷 prerequisite:

You must first know what you want to do.

AI won’t decide your life direction. It won’t generate desires for you.

It only responds to:

  • Problems
  • Hypotheses
  • Goals
  • Paths

Yet many people’s daily state is:

  • Passively binge-watching shows
  • Passively scrolling videos
  • Passively working
  • Passively waiting for opportunities

Ask them what they want, and after thinking they say:

“I want to get rich overnight.”

This statement itself declares AI’s uselessness.

Why “Get Rich Quick” Is AI’s Nemesis

Section titled “Why “Get Rich Quick” Is AI’s Nemesis”

Because it’s not a goal—it’s an escapist fantasy.

Its subtext is:

  • I don’t want to think about the process
  • I don’t want to own the journey
  • I only want the result

AI is precisely the opposite.

AI excels at exactly one thing:

Making “what you’re already thinking about” clearer.

If you think about nothing, hoping the world suddenly changes—what you need isn’t AI. It’s luck, lottery tickets, or miracles.

Binge-Watching vs AI: Two Opposite Systems

Section titled “Binge-Watching vs AI: Two Opposite Systems”

Many don’t realize:

AI is the first mass technology that doesn’t serve escapism.

Binge-watching shows and scrolling short videos share:

  • No intention needed
  • No choices needed
  • No responsibility needed

You just “continue to next.”

AI’s interface seems gentle, but its core is cold:

  • You don’t ask, it doesn’t move
  • You ask unclearly, it exposes your confusion
  • You don’t give direction, it spins in place

Some instinctively reject it. Not because it’s hard to use, but because it reflects their empty-spinning state.

Why Not Using AI Is Becoming a “Generation Gap”

Section titled “Why Not Using AI Is Becoming a “Generation Gap””

Over the past year, AI hasn’t been “improving efficiency”—it’s been restructuring cognitive division of labor:

HumanAI
Judgment, stance, trade-offsExpansion, verification, parallel execution, compression

Not using AI means:

  • All thinking runs only in your own brain
  • All trial and error costs your personal time
  • Once problem complexity rises, you immediately struggle

Short-term, they can still work. But long-term, their ceiling is locked.

A Less Polite but Real Conclusion

Section titled “A Less Polite but Real Conclusion”

It’s not that AI abandoned many people.

Rather, many people were never on the path that “needs AI” from the start.

They don’t need an amplifier because there’s nothing worth amplifying.

What they need is:

  • Distraction
  • Anesthesia
  • Miracles

Not:

  • Thinking
  • Reasoning
  • Action paths

The Final Line (The Boundary)

Section titled “The Final Line (The Boundary)”

AI belongs only to those who have started taking responsibility for their lives.

If you’re already thinking:

  • What do I want to change?
  • What do I want to advance?
  • Where am I stuck?

Then AI becomes your external brain.

If you’re still at:

  • “Whatever, doesn’t matter”
  • “Let’s see what luck brings”
  • “Wait for opportunity”

Then saying AI is useless is completely correct.

Key Insights

Section titled “Key Insights”
InsightImplication
AI as AmplifierIt enhances what exists, doesn’t create from nothing
The PrerequisiteYou must know what you want before AI can help
Escapism vs EngagementAI requires active participation, unlike passive entertainment
Cognitive DivisionHumans judge; AI expands, verifies, and compresses
The BoundaryAI serves those taking responsibility for their direction

The Deeper Question

Section titled “The Deeper Question”

This reflection raises an important question for all of us:

Are we using AI, or avoiding the mirror it holds up?

AI doesn’t just amplify our productivity—it amplifies our clarity of purpose. Those who find it useless may be discovering something uncomfortable: they may not have a purpose to amplify.

References

Section titled “References”
  • Original Thread by @naki2012
