item.title: TEN Framework: Open-Source Framework for Conversational Voice AI Agents
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

TEN Framework is an open-source framework for real-time multimodal conversational AI agents. It enables developers to easily build intelligent applications with voice, vision, and avatar capabilities.

Official Website: https://theten.ai/ GitHub: https://github.com/TEN-framework/ten-framework

The TEN ecosystem includes several core components:

  • TEN Framework: Core conversational AI agent framework
  • TEN VAD: Low-latency, lightweight streaming voice activity detector
  • TEN Turn Detection: Enables full-duplex dialogue communication
  • TEN Portal: Official documentation and blog site
  • Agent Examples: Rich collection of use case examples

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Multi-Purpose Voice Assistant

Section titled “Multi-Purpose Voice Assistant”

TEN Framework provides low-latency, high-quality real-time voice assistants supporting both RTC and WebSocket connections. Easily extend with:

  • Memory: Remember conversation history
  • VAD: Voice Activity Detection for intelligent speech recognition
  • Turn Detection: Natural dialogue flow management

Avatar Integration

Section titled “Avatar Integration”

Support for multiple avatar providers:

  • Live2D: Anime-style virtual characters (e.g., Kei with MotionSync lip-sync)
  • Trulience: Realistic 3D avatars
  • HeyGen: High-quality AI virtual humans
  • Tavus: Personalized avatars

Speech Diarization & Transcription

Section titled “Speech Diarization & Transcription”
  • Real-time diarization: Detect and label different speakers
  • Transcription tools: Convert audio to text in real-time

SIP Phone Integration

Section titled “SIP Phone Integration”

Connect AI agents with traditional telephone networks through SIP extension, supporting services like Twilio.

Hardware Integration

Section titled “Hardware Integration”

Support for ESP32-S3 Korvo V3 development board, enabling LLM-powered communication on hardware devices.

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
CategoryRequirements
API Keys• Agora App ID & Certificate
• OpenAI API key
• Deepgram ASR key
• ElevenLabs TTS key
Installation• Docker / Docker Compose
• Node.js (LTS) v18+
System Requirements• CPU >= 2 cores
• RAM >= 4 GB

Local Setup

Section titled “Local Setup”

Configure .env file:

Start services:

Run examples:

Visit http://localhost:3000/ for the example interface and http://localhost:49483/ for TMAN Designer to configure extensions.

Docker Deployment

Section titled “Docker Deployment”

Build custom image:

Run image:

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

1. Intelligent Customer Service

Section titled “1. Intelligent Customer Service”

Combine VAD and Turn Detection for smooth, natural AI customer service experiences.

2. Virtual Streamers

Section titled “2. Virtual Streamers”

Use Live2D or realistic avatars for 24/7 automated live streaming and interaction.

3. Voice Assistants

Section titled “3. Voice Assistants”

Build personal voice assistants like Siri/Alexa with memory capabilities.

4. Meeting Assistants

Section titled “4. Meeting Assistants”

Real-time transcription, speaker diarization, and meeting summary generation.

5. Education & Training

Section titled “5. Education & Training”

AI language learning partners for real-time conversation practice and correction.

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Extension Development

Section titled “1. Extension Development”

Customize agent behavior through TMAN Designer or by editing property.json directly.

2. Performance Optimization

Section titled “2. Performance Optimization”
  • Use TEN VAD instead of third-party VAD services to reduce latency
  • Enable Turn Detection for more natural dialogue flows

3. Deployment Architecture

Section titled “3. Deployment Architecture”

Separate frontend and backend deployment:

  • Backend: Run on any Docker-compatible platform (VM, Fly.io, Render, ECS, Cloud Run)
  • Frontend: Deploy to Vercel or Netlify, communicate via API with backend

Considerations

Section titled “Considerations”

API Costs

Section titled “API Costs”

TEN Framework itself is free and open-source, but depends on third-party services:

  • OpenAI: Billed per token
  • Deepgram: Billed by usage duration
  • ElevenLabs: Billed per character
  • Agora: Free tier available, then billed per minute

License

Section titled “License”
  • TEN Framework core uses Apache License 2.0
  • Components in packages directory are independently released
  • Third-party libraries detailed in third_party folder

Community Support

Section titled “Community Support”
  • Discord: Developer community
  • GitHub Issues: Bug reports and feature requests
  • Documentation: https://theten.ai/docs

References

Section titled “References”
  • TEN Framework GitHub
  • Official Documentation
  • Example Code
  • TEN VAD
  • TEN Turn Detection

Keywords: TEN Framework, Voice AI, Agents, Open Source, Conversational AI, VAD, Real-time Voice

item.title: VibeCoding: The Blueprint for Fully Automated Product Building in 2026
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

A new paradigm shift is happening in software development. What started as AI-assisted coding has evolved into something far more powerful: VibeCoding - a methodology where developers and AI agents collaborate to build products with unprecedented speed and autonomy.

Coined by AI researcher Andrej Karpathy, VibeCoding represents more than just using AI to write code. It’s a complete reimagining of how software products are conceived, built, and shipped. In 2026, solo developers using VibeCoding methodologies are launching products in weeks that would have traditionally taken teams months to build.

Understanding VibeCoding

Section titled “Understanding VibeCoding”

What is VibeCoding?

Section titled “What is VibeCoding?”

VibeCoding is the practice of building software by describing what you want to an AI system and letting it create the product for you. Unlike traditional coding where you write every line manually, VibeCoding focuses on:

  • Intent-driven development: You describe the outcome, AI handles the implementation
  • Autonomous workflows: AI agents perform complex multi-step tasks independently
  • Iterative refinement: Quick feedback loops between human intent and AI execution
  • Context-aware assistance: AI maintains understanding of your entire project

The Evolution from AI-Assisted to Autonomous

Section titled “The Evolution from AI-Assisted to Autonomous”

The VibeCoding Blueprint

Section titled “The VibeCoding Blueprint”

Phase 1: Vision and Specification

Section titled “Phase 1: Vision and Specification”

Goal: Translate your idea into a clear, actionable specification

In VibeCoding, clarity of intent is your primary tool. You don’t write code - you write specifications that AI can execute:

  1. Define the problem: What pain point are you solving?
  2. Specify requirements: What must the product do?
  3. Describe the experience: How should it feel to use?
  4. Set constraints: What technologies, platforms, or limitations apply?

Example Specification:

Phase 2: Architecture Planning

Section titled “Phase 2: Architecture Planning”

Goal: Let AI design the system architecture

Modern AI coding assistants (Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot Workspace) can:

  • Design database schemas based on your requirements
  • Plan API endpoints and data flow
  • Suggest technology stacks optimized for your use case
  • Identify potential issues before writing code

Phase 3: Autonomous Implementation

Section titled “Phase 3: Autonomous Implementation”

Goal: AI agents build while you oversee and guide

This is where VibeCoding shines. Using tools like:

  • Claude Code: Long-context AI that can reason through entire codebases
  • Multi-agent systems: Specialized agents for frontend, backend, testing
  • MCP (Model Context Protocol): AI tools can directly interact with your environment

The workflow looks like:

Phase 4: Iterative Refinement

Section titled “Phase 4: Iterative Refinement”

Goal: Quick feedback loops for rapid improvement

VibeCoding excels at iteration because changes are conversation, not manual labor:

  • “Make the dashboard dark mode”
  • “Add export to CSV functionality”
  • “Optimize this slow query”
  • “Refactor this component for reusability”

Each request is handled autonomously by AI, while you focus on product decisions.

Core Components of a VibeCoding Stack

Section titled “Core Components of a VibeCoding Stack”

1. The AI Coding Environment

Section titled “1. The AI Coding Environment”
ToolStrengthBest For
Claude Code200K+ context, strong reasoningComplex architecture, full-featured apps
CursorVS Code integration, fastDaily coding, quick iterations
GitHub CopilotWide language supportEnterprise development
v0.devUI-first generationFrontend prototypes

2. Agent Orchestration

Section titled “2. Agent Orchestration”

Advanced VibeCoders use multi-agent systems:

  • Architect Agent: Designs system structure
  • Frontend Agent: Builds UI components
  • Backend Agent: Implements APIs and business logic
  • QA Agent: Writes and runs tests
  • Documentation Agent: Maintains docs alongside code

3. Context Management

Section titled “3. Context Management”

Your AI needs deep context about your project:

  • Project overview: Goals, constraints, patterns
  • Codebase understanding: File structure, conventions
  • Decision log: Why certain choices were made
  • Active work: Current task, blockers, next steps

This is often maintained in:

  • CLAUDE.md or AI_INSTRUCTIONS.md files
  • Project wikis or notepads
  • Specialized context tools (Claude Code memories)

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

When VibeCoding Shines

Section titled “When VibeCoding Shines”

Perfect for:

  • 🚀 MVP Development: Launch quickly to validate ideas
  • 🔧 Internal Tools: Build custom productivity solutions
  • 🎨 Prototyping: Explore multiple design directions fast
  • 📚 Learning: Understand codebases by having AI explain them
  • 🔄 Refactoring: Modernize legacy code systematically

Less Ideal for:

  • ⚡ Ultra-low-latency systems requiring hand-tuned optimization
  • 🔒 High-security environments requiring audit trails
  • 🏢 Enterprise systems with rigid compliance requirements

Daily Workflow Example

Section titled “Daily Workflow Example”

A typical day in VibeCoding might look like:

Compare this to traditional development where each step requires manual coding.

Success Patterns

Section titled “Success Patterns”
  1. Spec-First Development: Write clear specifications before coding
  2. Incremental Verification: Test each piece before moving on
  3. Context Maintenance: Keep AI informed about project state
  4. Acceptance Criteria: Define “done” before starting work
  5. Regular Reviews: Human oversight catches edge cases

Precautions and Challenges

Section titled “Precautions and Challenges”

Common Pitfalls

Section titled “Common Pitfalls”

Over-reliance on AI:

  • Don’t accept code without understanding it
  • Review architectural decisions
  • Maintain ability to debug without AI

Vague Requirements:

  • AI needs clarity to be effective
  • Ambiguity leads to rework
  • Invest time in good specifications

Context Loss:

  • AI forgets details over long sessions
  • Maintain persistent context files
  • Re-establish context for new sessions

Quality Control:

  • AI can write working but suboptimal code
  • Establish testing standards
  • Use code reviews even with AI

Managing Expectations

Section titled “Managing Expectations”

VibeCoding isn’t magic - it has limitations:

  • Complex reasoning: Humans still needed for novel problems
  • Taste and judgment: AI can’t substitute product intuition
  • Responsibility: You remain accountable for the code
  • Learning curve: Effective VibeCoding requires practice

Collaboration with Traditional Development

Section titled “Collaboration with Traditional Development”

Hybrid Teams

Section titled “Hybrid Teams”

VibeCoding can enhance traditional teams:

  • Seniors + AI: Multiply senior developer impact
  • Juniors + AI: Accelerate learning and productivity
  • Specialists + AI: Fill gaps in expertise

Communication

Section titled “Communication”

When working with teams using VibeCoding:

  • Document AI-assisted work clearly
  • Maintain version control discipline
  • Share specifications, not just code
  • Establish review processes

Comparative Analysis

Section titled “Comparative Analysis”

VibeCoding vs. Traditional Development

Section titled “VibeCoding vs. Traditional Development”
AspectTraditionalVibeCoding
Speed to MVP3-6 months1-4 weeks
Team Size3-10+ developers1-2 people
Primary SkillCode syntaxProblem specification
Iteration CycleDays to weeksHours to days
Learning CurveYears of codingWeeks of prompting
BottleneckDeveloper bandwidthClarity of requirements

VibeCoding vs. No-Code Platforms

Section titled “VibeCoding vs. No-Code Platforms”
AspectNo-CodeVibeCoding
FlexibilityLimited to platformUnlimited
Code OwnershipVendor lock-inFull ownership
CustomizationTemplate constraintsAnything possible
ScalabilityPlatform limitsYour infrastructure
LearningPlatform-specificTransferable skills

Tools and Ecosystem

Section titled “Tools and Ecosystem”

Essential VibeCoding Tools (2026)

Section titled “Essential VibeCoding Tools (2026)”

AI Coding Environments:

  • Claude Code - Best for complex projects
  • Cursor - Best daily driver IDE
  • v0.dev - Best for rapid UI prototyping

Agent Frameworks:

  • BMad Method - Structured agent workflows
  • OpenAI Swarm - Multi-agent orchestration
  • LangGraph - Complex agent flows

Context Management:

  • Claude Code Memories - Persistent project context
  • Continue.dev - Local AI context

Testing & QA:

  • E2B - AI code evaluation
  • KlingAI - Automated testing agents

The Future of VibeCoding

Section titled “The Future of VibeCoding”

Emerging Trends

Section titled “Emerging Trends”
  1. Specialized Agents: Domain-specific AI for frontend, backend, DevOps
  2. Voice-First Development: Describe changes verbally, watch code update
  3. Visual Development: Point at UI elements, describe changes
  4. Self-Healing Systems: AI that detects and fixes its own bugs
  5. Collaborative AI: Multiple AIs collaborating on complex projects

2026 Predictions

Section titled “2026 Predictions”
  • VibeCoding will be standard in 60% of startups
  • AI agents will handle 80% of routine development tasks
  • Developer roles shift from “coder” to “architect and reviewer”
  • New job titles: “AI Orchestrator”, “VibeCoding Product Lead”

Getting Started

Section titled “Getting Started”

Your First VibeCoding Project

Section titled “Your First VibeCoding Project”
  1. Choose your tool: Start with Claude Code or Cursor
  2. Pick a simple project: Todo app, portfolio site, internal tool
  3. Write a clear spec: Define what you want to build
  4. Let AI lead: Ask AI to design the architecture first
  5. Iterate conversationally: Guide AI through refinement
  6. Learn by doing: Pay attention to AI’s approach and decisions

Learning Resources

Section titled “Learning Resources”
  • Awesome VibeCoding - Curated resources
  • VibeCoding Wikipedia - Official definition
  • Google Cloud VibeCoding Guide - Enterprise perspective
  • Plain English VibeCoding 2026 - Real playbook

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

VibeCoding represents a fundamental shift in how software is built. It’s not just about writing code faster - it’s about rethinking the entire development process around human-AI collaboration.

For solo developers and small teams, VibeCoding levels the playing field. You can now build products that previously required teams and months of work. For larger organizations, it offers a path to dramatically increased productivity.

The key to success with VibeCoding is clarity of intent. The better you can describe what you want, the better AI can deliver it. Invest time in specifications, maintain good context, and always review the output.

The future of software development is here - and it’s a conversation between human creativity and AI capability.
